text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
ROMANIA LIBERA
- New free trade zone will become operational at Danube port of Giurgiu.
TINERETUL LIBER
- Nuclear reactor at Cernavoda is undergoing tests at full capacity.
- Industry Ministry sources say $3.0 billion are needed to reequip and upgrade Romania's metallurgy.
LIBERTATEA

- Romanian Intelligence Service's (SRI) 1996 report to parliament shows SRI supplied information on illegal credits granted by commercial banks Banca Dacia Felix SA and Renasterea Creditului Romanesc Credit Bank, forecasting their eventual decline.
General:
ROMANIA LIBERA

- "Romania has one solution left -- to elect as president a person with no political past and not linked to Russia, which wants to keep former communist countries under its influence," says the newspaper quoting Frazer Cameron from European Commission.
- Two-page report on reform in education system through alternative school books.
- Newspaper publishes report on suicide and desertions in Romania's army.
ADEVARUL

- A priest, quack doctor and a leader of car drivers running for presidency in the November 3 polls is sign of despair indicating the population wants who ever except President Ion Iliescu as president, says editorial.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- Newspaper publishes agenda of pop star Michael Jackson's visit to Bucharest where is is to hold a concert of HIStory tour on Saturday.
- Newspaper publishes excerpt from the 1996 annual report of the Romanian Intelligence Service which says the Italian mafia wants to control hotels, casinos and shops in Romania.
- National Unity Party (PUNR) leader Gheorghe Funar said Romanians from the diaspora will be on the party's list for parliament.
LIBERTATEA

- Children's health is electoral battle theme, reads front page headline on dispute between Bucharest's mayor, of opposition Democratic Convention (CDR) who ordered schools to stay shut for another two weeks due to a meningitis epidemic and health and education ministers, members of ruling Party of Social Democracy (PDSR) who refuse the delay in school start.
CRONICA ROMANA
- Interview with Ioan Gavra, PUNR vice-president, saying President Iliescu and Prime Minister Nicoale Vacaroiu should be dismissed over accepting the Romanian-Hungarian treaty.
- President Iliescu was given a diploma for special contributions.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Opinion poll by the Romanian newspaper and the Hungarian daily Magyar Hirlap on Romanian-Hungarian treaty.
VREMEA

- President Iliescu and (former premier) Petre Roman must not be elected, they don't even deserve to run for presidency, says Ion Coja, senator of opposition Democratic Agrarian Party (PDAR) in interview. ($=3,177 lei) -- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
